ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Married applicants under 21 years of age)


    1. Encik Harun Bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many married couples under the age of 21 have applied to purchase or rent Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats from 1998-2000; (b) how many

Column: 1134

such applications were rejected; and (c) whether the HDB will relax its rules to enable such couples to buy or rent the flats in the future.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB does not allow married couples under the age of 21 to purchase HDB flats on their own. This is because persons below the age of 21 are deemed not to have the legal capacity to enter into any contract for the purchase of a flat. Such couples can consider applying for HDB flats with their parents as co-applicants, or staying with their parents until either one of them attains the age of 21 years. HDB does not keep records on the number of flat applications that were rejected due to both parties being underage.

    Likewise, an applicant applying to rent a HDB flat must be at least 21 years old. Between 1998 and 2000, HDB rejected seven applications to rent HDB flats from married couples who are both below 21 years old.

    As the legal age of majority in Singapore is still 21 years old, HDB has no plan to lower the minimum age criterion for the purchase or rental of a HDB flat.

    The Chairman: Head L - Ministry of Education. Amendment No. (1), Dr Wang Kai Yuen.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head L of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the education of our children is a subject close to our hearts. Every parent with a child in our school system has suggestions on how to improve it. Some of these ideas sound very logical and it is tempting to tweak the system to incorporate them. For instance, when pupil workload was identified to be an issue, we reduced the course load. Sir, I surmise that step-wise improvements are useful, provided we are already very happy with our existing system. But sometimes it might be better if we perform a total review and, where necessary, implement system-wide changes.

    Sir, what we have got today is a very good system, highly productive and efficient. All we have to do is to look at the recent 'A' and 'O' level results, and from that perspective, it is a system any education authority in the world would envy.

    Ours is a system designed by systems engineers where pupils are sorted according to their learning abilities. From primary 4 onwards, the school children are graded every two years, and streamed to different ability streams. After 'O' level, they are channelled into different career paths according to their examination results. Some 20% go on to universities, another 40% to the polytechnics and the rest to ITE. It is a traditional system where rote learning and discipline pay great dividends. As a result, we send our children to schools to be educated. They ended up being on a treadmill whose speed is being cranked up one notch every so often, because there is a need to separate the outstanding from the merely good. Stress is high. And our children end up spending most of their time poring

Column: 1136

over books and pitifully little time in other activities such as sports that school-going children in other countries are engaged in. Many of our children do not enjoy school, even though they score very well in their examinations.

    Sir, I think it is worthwhile for us to note that almost every education system in the world requires a 12-year education for the children before they are admitted into the university. This minimum period seems to be a universal norm. Perhaps it has something to do with the maturing process of the human mind. However, because of our singular focus on knowledge acquisition, at every level of our school system, our children out-perform their counterparts in other countries, in particular, some of the western countries. But once our young men and women graduated from a 4-year university degree programme, I surmise that they emerge no better than the graduates from other overseas universities. So, the advantage gained in our school system seems, to me, to be short-term ones. Therefore, my question is: is it necessary to subject our children to study so much, be subject to so much stress prior to entering university when, after graduation, they are almost back to the same level as others from a less stressful education system?

    Furthermore, I think it is well-known in the university education circle that no matter how we design the sorting system, be it examinations or otherwise, it is very likely that the same strong students will always emerge at the top. Sir, if that is the case, and if we do not have permanent long-term advantages, the question then is: why do we put our children through a pressure cooker system, so much so that one young girl even took her own life for failing to meet up to her own expectations? I note that Dr Lily Neo has a cut on this subject and I would not go into this further.

    For years now, the Government has asserted that the stress in the education system is not there as a result of any Government policy. The Minister has, in fact, responded on many occasions that even if he instructed the schools to ban all

Column: 1137

homework, it would not have changed the situation at all. The simple reason is that the parents would then step in, take over and hire tutors to ensure that their children stay on top. So, who is responsible for the stress in our education system - the parents or the system itself?

    Sir, parents' behaviours are indeed rational and logical. They want the best for their children. They are equipping their children for the best jobs in the job market. I surmise that they are just responding to the way our system selects candidates to fill the best jobs in the job market, in particular, when they first graduate from the university. At that stage, because of our transparency and our emphasis on meritocracy, individuals are chosen by the civil service, the GLCs and statutory boards based almost exclusively on their academic achievements. Furthermore, because we have a scholarship system, these candidates are chosen soon after their 'A' level examination results, when most of them are just 18 years old. For the creme de la creme, good jobs and well-smoothened career paths await the scholastic high achievers. This is epitomised by the public service, which only picks the very best.

    In fact, there is no easier way to pick them than to base on scholastic achievement at that time. I believe this is what drives the competitive engine in our education system. Examinations must be designed to separate the few at the apex from the mere outstanding. At the last 'A' level results, the number of students with 4 As, if you look at the report, is in fact very staggering. Since we can no longer separate the cream from the mere outstanding, we introduced the S paper into the examinations. This intensity to get better and better results in the examinations percolates down the whole system, from pre-university all the way to primary school.

    Therefore, if we were to address how to improve our approach to education, reducing course load to the students itself is not enough. We will still need to change the culture, starting with changing the selection process for the best jobs in the

Column: 1138

job market. In this area, the Government will have to take the lead if we are indeed committed to changing the culture. To start with, we should change the way candidates for the best jobs in the civil service are selected. We should de-emphasise scholastic achievements and focus on demonstrated abilities. Perhaps we can learn from the Singapore Armed Forces how they select the officers, where the total capability of the individual is assessed.

    Another possibility is for the Administrative Service to rely less on scholars, fresh out of the university, and to tap matured talents from the open job market. If the rest of the GLCs and the statutory boards take the cue, we could be on our way to change the culture. Once that message is made loud and clear, I am sure the behaviour of the parents and students will change accordingly.

    Of course, changing the culture of the whole society is not the task of MOE alone, but might require a policy decision by the Cabinet. But change we must in order for Singapore to continue to do well in the knowledge-based economy. Creativity and innovation are key to the wealth creating process in the KBE. And without change, our current education system would be found wanting.

    Sir, the Minister has given much thought to this issue. I think the House would benefit from his comments on this topic.

    Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam): Sir, a common refrain and lament we hear these days are the heavy workload and stress faced by students and teachers. Here, I want to echo the GPC Chairman for Education, Dr Wang Kai Yuen, on the points he made. Thus we hear the chorus of complaints about the misgivings expressed in the school ranking, students being streamed into Gifted and Special Assistance Programme, Express and Normal streams, class size could be smaller and the declining mental health of our children. Sir, I believe the basic concern is really the fear of parents that their child may not be able to cope and do well in school.

Column: 1139



    Indeed, the pace of change has been frantic. So many things are happening. I fear that our children are spending too much time on the computers, since the time that we introduced IT in schools. There are non-academic subjects and healthy sports and recreational activities which our children should be learning and doing, but are not. There are so many demands, yet the time and resources are limited. We have to take stock of the individual's capacity and capability and help them prioritize accordingly. We have to help our children to organise themselves and manage their time better as we adults do.

    Parents should know that their children have at least 40 years of active working life ahead of them. To have a headstart is to lay a strong foundation. It requires patient nurturing. If the children need more time, we ought to give it to them. We may wish to be quick, but we should not be in a hurry, because we understand "make haste, less speed". Even more important is the inculcation of good values and sound principles in our young. Parents themselves must set the right and good example for their children. We seem to be doing things for our young instead of showing them how.

    We have to accept that our children have different gifts and talent endowments. We should not ask the children to do courses and subjects that they are not interested in. That is why we see a growing number of them dropping out of medicine, legal practice and accountancy after graduation. A common reason offered was that they were doing it for their parents. How sad, they should be doing it for themselves and be proud of it. Mind you, we are talking about very noble professions.

    The Ministry of Education can actively embark on a comprehensive programme to guide the parents as to how they should educate their children at home. Perhaps in partnership between the teachers and

Column: 1140

parents, we can achieve better outcome in the progress and overall development of our children.

    May I ask the Minister how he proposes to address the common concern of heavy workload and stressful schooling and the consequential effects on our parents, teachers and students?

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, last year, I spoke about the education system that is mainly focused on the efficiency of delivery of subjects and lessons and therefore we have achieved well in terms of measures like scoring straight `A's, ranking of schools based on academic excellence and achieving top marks in international Science and Mathematics competition. The issue therefore is whether the efficient education system has allowed us to produce good innovators, entrepreneurs, artists, sportsmen and women of excellence in non-academic areas. The real answer is that we have limited success in these areas. My main question to the Minister is: what has he done in implementing the `mass customisation' approach in our education system? Can the Minister give specifics of what he really means by the mass customisation programme and how he plans to implement this in schools? To-date, I am still confused as to what it means and not able to see the concrete examples of implementation. Are our schools set up to allow customisation of education for our children of differing abilities or are we just categorising our children according to academic learning abilities, like we have been doing in the past? How are we ensuring that the system we have in place is able to identify non-academic talents and groom students of such talents to achieve their full potential? Does our school system consider grooming students to achieve excellence in such non-academic areas as important as those who have done well in academic areas? I have to admit that to-date, I have not been able to see any significant impact of the mass customisation plans.

    I have spoken about streaming of our children at the Primary 4 level and I would like to touch on this again today. Our

Column: 1141

children are so stressed these days, as we have heard from our previous two speakers, that I do not think many of them enjoy going to school. How then can we inculcate the value of lifelong learning if they get disillusioned by our education system at such an early age? I have seen in my daughter's school, it was examination period, where a girl was struggling not to go for her test, and her parents were pulling her on one end and the teacher and the principal were all encouraging her to go. It was really a very distracting sight for the children around her too.

    If we survey all the education systems around the world, we are the only country in the world that does streaming at such an early age. While the intended outcome is to allow every child to learn at his or her pace, the actual outcome is that we label them and eliminate them or greatly reduce their chances of getting back to the mainstream Express or Normal (Academic) streams. Can the Minister give statistics of how many children streamed to the EM3 stream have made it back to EM1 or EM2 streams in the primary schools? And how many EM3 students, who went to the Normal (Technical) stream, made it back to the Normal (Academic) and Express streams?

    Sir, I attended a function recently organised by CDAC, MENDAKI and SINDA. This is called Project Team, and we have heard about it in this House recently. The programme was intended to bring children of various races and streams together in trying to inculcate a sense of community and bond-building among themselves. When I actually asked some of them, many of them right from the beginning when they got together, segregated themselves according to the streams that they came from, and basically treated each other differently. Those from the lower streams seem to be having self-esteem issue and those from the higher streams seem to have a `high-class' feeling issue. If we start to develop this kind of attitude at early ages, we will see real problems when they grow up as adults in the country.

Column: 1142



    I am also curious to find out what programmes have been put in place to promote creativity and lifelong learning in our schools. Particularly, have there been any changes in the curriculum which develop the creative mind and inculcate the value of lifelong learning? I myself have not seen any evidence of this being done. In fact, we still continue to focus on the academic issues and measures, and therefore there have not been many changes. And I do not think we will see any impact in trying to develop creativity and the issue of lifelong learning among our children.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, lest we get carried away with the notion that our education system is full of warts and problems, I do want to bring the focus back to the point that, overall, we have a good education system. Certainly that is the feedback I get from parents and, in general, observers both within and outside Singapore. I think the fact that we are raising issues that are qualitative in nature suggests that we want to make it even better. It would be a far greater cause of concern for us if we are complaining about the quality of the instruction we get in our schools, or that our students are not measuring up when we compare them with international standards.

    Sir, in part, that is due to the various initiatives that the Ministry has undertaken over the last few years, in particular, focusing on the hardware in terms of improving facilities, the systems through school evaluation models and information technology, and so on. Also, it has demonstrated a focus on perhaps the most important element - the teachers, the people who make the system work. In that regard, the terms of employment for teachers are important. Salaries and benefits are an essential part. One does not want to over-emphasise this because I think there is more to a career than just the pay and the benefits, but this is an essential element. And I would be pleased to know from the Minister what initiatives would be taken in that regard.

    Perhaps, as importantly, what other initiatives are being undertaken to enhance

Column: 1143

the work experience of our teachers in the school environment? A common complaint is administrative load, and that leading to stress. Are there other measures we can undertake through employment of additional support staff or in terms of providing them with customised IT solutions which might minimise these forms of burden in the eyes of the teachers so that they can concentrate on what they do best, which is, teach students.

    Sir, one feedback that we have obtained from the GPC for Education is that perhaps in our education system, a certain prosaic utilitarian attitude is emerging. Evidence of that would be in the form of the choice of subjects our students seem to be gravitating towards, with a particular emphasis on the Sciences and Mathematics and away from the softer, harder-to-score subjects like the Humanities. We have heard that in some of the top schools, due to emphasis among the students themselves, by choice, there would appear to be a move away from English Literature. If they must do an Arts subject and as required by the schools, they would prefer to do history or geography, because it is easier to score than to do Literature, which generally, it seems, is a harder subject in which to get an `A' or a distinction. This is attributable to many causes - that we over-emphasise Science and Mathematics, that schools are too geared towards achieving quantitative results, because of the ranking system.

    But, Sir, whatever the cause, the question really is: is this an example of market failure perhaps in our education system? In this day and age, when we are emphasising a broad-based education where we want to ensure that our students come out with the capability to channel their energy in a broad range of areas of endeavour, because the needs of the environment, the economy, and our society are changing so fast, would it not be important for us to ensure that our students have a broad-based approach in their attitude towards education?

Column: 1144



    I would like to ask the Minister: is this a cause for concern at this point? Is there a marked trend? If it is, is it a cause for concern? In particular, is this an example of perhaps a market failure where some form of Government intervention might be justified? Just as, for example, one could argue that the choice of mother tongue as an academic subject might not be high on the list of priority for a student because of the difficulty to score points, but the Government has seen fit to emphasise it as an essential part of education process. Could we adopt a similar attitude towards the humanities? If we do adopt such an attitude, how can we structure the system to ensure that this becomes an essential part of the total education experience our students have in schools?

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Sir, our education system continues to be a topic that generates what we should perhaps simply describe as "animated conversation" where anywhere and anytime, you find a gathering of Singaporeans who are parents.

    The four Members before me have spoken on various aspects of our education system that cause stress and distress to parents and children. Sir, we have a dilemma. The Ministry's view is that the fundamental problem lies in parents' unrealistic expectations of their children. Parents, on the other hand, are equally convinced that the problem essentially resides in the rigidity of an unforgiving system. When you analyse the stories and experiences recounted, the issues may be grouped largely into three categories.

    The first relates to the thorny issue of our values - our practice of reducing everything to economics, of measuring success and the dollars and cents that come with the high-paying jobs that come to those with academic achievements that drive our parents to drive their children.

    The second set relates to the many individual anecdotes of teachers who are less sensitive and less nurturing than what

Column: 1145

would be considered adequate and satisfactory to guide and help our children develop to the best of their abilities.

    The third set relates to principals. The Ministry has on occasions before pointed out that it has over the years been responsive in reviewing policies, for example, in reducing curriculum load. Therefore, a number of operational issues, such as, for example, starting times of the school day, principals have been given full autonomy to make decisions. It seems, however, that some principals may be over-zealous in pursuing academic results and rankings on the one hand, or possibly not taking advantage of the autonomy delegated to them on the other. However, when you hear good stories of good schools, invariably, I think, you will find a good principal with initiative, supporting and managing his or her staff well.

    Sir, if you look at the problem of values, that is something that the Ministry of Education cannot solve on its own and which takes a long time to evolve and resolve. When you look at the anecdotes that relate to teachers, I really do not know how one can go about ensuring that 25,000 teachers perform consistently up to the standards that we all want for the instruction of our children. So it seems to me that the best bet we may have that would enable a more immediate better management of parents' anxieties and frustrations is to pull out all stops and focus on the identification and accelerated development of good dynamic principles to optimise the management of resources and operation of issues and the insightful implementation of policies at individual school level. I recognise that 300-plus good principals sound a lot more manageable a number than 25,000 good teachers. But it is still a tall order. However, by grouping or clustering schools together and the assignment of particularly strong principals so that they may be well distributed among the clusters could achieve a multiplier effect.

    There is one more thing, Sir, that is needed and that is to be sure that the

Column: 1146

measures of performance must be clear and consistent with policy directions so that principals are not incentivised to behave in incongruent ways. In other words, for example, the Ministry says that ranking of schools in academic performance is not the be-all and the end-all and other things are important too, then principals' performance, appraisal and progress in their careers should reflect that.

    I hope that the Minister will take my observations into consideration as an attempt at a shorter term solution even as we grapple with the longer term and even more difficult to resolve issues and challenges in the education of our children.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, the Ministry of Education has been scoring highly in preparing Singaporean children academically and is now endeavouring to further educate and equip them to face the information technology and new economy age. Thus far, MOE has been concentrating more on imparting knowledge to the children.

    But, for an ideal education, MOE should treat the education of our children in a more holistic way. The well-being of the children, such as their mental state, their social requirements and their physical needs, should be the concern of all the teachers as well.

    Sir, teachers should not just concentrate on teaching them the academic syllabus. They are very much in contact with our children and are ideally suited to take added interest and be concerned with their students in a more holistic way. They should also teach and help them cope with life. I am not, in any way, suggesting that we diminish the responsibilities of parents. I am suggesting that teachers be equipped with skills and encouraged to identify students with difficulties, be it social, mental or even financial, and refer them for assistance.

    In 1998, 2,358 new cases of children aged below 18 were registered at the Government psychiatric clinics. As mentioned earlier by Dr Wang Kai Yuen,

Column: 1147

only recently, a 12-year old student jumped to her death. Sir, could stress, maybe due to the heavy school load or the unrealistic expectations of parents, be the cause? Perhaps, our children should also be taught how to cope with stress from young to attain their maximum potential. The early detection of those children who are vulnerable to stress will save them from poor performance and mental breakdown.

    To be effective, schools have no choice but to get involved with some parents. This area must be expanded. Often times, we need to solve problems at the root and sometimes the parents may have to be advised. Sir, it would also be worthwhile for the Ministry of Education and the schools to put in more effort to alleviate the anxiety and better inform the parents on issues, such as streaming, banding, and so on.

    A holistic and comprehensive education would be ideal in helping parents with school-going kids balance work and family commitments. We may, perhaps, try matching work hours with school hours. Sir, since we are tending towards single session schools, we can have the children stay back in the school to do "homework" or have "remedials" whilst their parents are still at work.
